dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER CRAWFORD is just reaching orgasm - - with ROB NUNALLY: mid-30s, good-looking, aging-boyish. They clutch each other, shuddering, lost in passion. And then, breathing heavily, caressing each other - Nunally r off her - slowly coming back to earth. Jennifer studies her lover, a quiet play of relief and gratitude and satisfaction on her face - - darkened by a troubled distance, maybe even fear. She is, after all, having an affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford stares through the grotesque lenses, motionless, expressionless. He takes a deep breath and checks his watch.   Then he st removing the glasses. We now see his office: large, austere. Decor and equipmen related to aircraft engineering. Outside big windows, jet take off from an industrial airstrip. Crawford gets a brand-new bottle of Jack Daniels from a d drawer, uncaps it and swigs as he opens the door to a pri bathroom. He gargles, spits into the sink. He pours out more, then puts the half-empty bottle back on his desk. He collects a home-made device from the workbench: it loo like a PDA connected by wires to a blank credit card. He puts it in the pocket of his suit jacket, which he set the desk. Adjusts the placement of the open bottle, nearb Crawford goes to a light-box, studying a set of large X-r dark strips of welding in a grayish fuzz of metal. TINA, his assistant, appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The N.T.S.B. guys are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Doesn't look up) Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates a second, glancing at the bottle. Crawford ignores her, pulling an x-ray off the light-box grabbing his jacket - - which knocks over the bottle.   It skitters across the liquor spilling. Crawford just walks out past Tina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twisted, torn and burned wreckage of a large private is being reassembled on the big empty concrete floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N.T.S.B. INVESTIGATORS in shirtsleeves and AIRCRAFT COMPA EXECUTIVES in suits cluster around work-boards covered wi photographs and diagrams of a crash site. They look up, falling silent, as Crawford comes in carryi the X-ray. A few exchange surprised, concerned glances; t is not a man who skips a shave. But when he gets to them, Crawford is laser-like - holdin the X-ray and pointing to a spot three inches above it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands a startled Investigator the film and strides off toward the giant open doors out to the airfield. His foot knocks a piece of the carefully-laid-out wreckag passing; it clatters across the concrete, but Crawford doesn't slow or look back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob is still in the bed, naked under the sheet - watching Jennifer adjust the straps of her bathing suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, surprised.    Smiles, comes to sit besi him. Gently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go out to dinner - we might never come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Rob nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (Beat) I want to wake up with you.    I want to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gropes for words, but it's too big and he relents - sc back, sighing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...at least see where you live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She regards him tenderly, feeling the same reckless yearn But also fear. She rubs his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live...here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans over to kiss him delicately on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black Porsche speeds down a quiet street near the beach pulls into a parking space. Crawford gets out, goes to a pay phone. He puts his cell phone on top of it, drops in some change and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L.A.P.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Nunally, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens to hold music and checks the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't come on til six. You want his voice mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Thank you. (beat) I'll see him later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, grabs his cell, and takes off down the sidew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford enters. He knows where he's going - past the fro desk and outside to the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer swims laps with strong, even strokes.   Rob is enjoying the sun in a lounge chair. Crawford eyes them as he passes on the other side of a lo fence. Unnoticed, he heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford stops at a room with a DO NOT DISTURB sign on th knob. He takes out his PDA-device and slides its card int the key-card slot of the lock. The lock clicks to green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford enters, quietly closing the door behind him. He just stands there, taking it all in. The unmade bed, t ripped-open condom packet, the clothes on the floor. He is silent.   Very still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer drives her Mercedes convertible past expensive houses in the late-afternoon light. She goes up the driveway of the Crawfords' stark mordern Across the street, MR. GIFFORD is playing catch with his GRANDSON. He waves to Jennifer. She waves back, friendly but distracted, on her way to th front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold. Elegant. Metal planters with bamboo trees. Glass doors out to a back garden. A fire in the fireplace. In a corner is another of Crawford's Rube Goldbergs - thi one the size of a refrigerator. On a coffee table in the center of the room, a big wooden bowl of ball-bearings. Jennifer hurries in, dropping her keys on a table and - - freezes, startled. Crawford waits in the center of the room; despite the out "disarray", he is calm and focused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're - home early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just felt a sudden urge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you...okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford shrugs, smiling strangely.   He looks pained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could use a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer submits guiltily.   Crawford embraces her, tight She waits it out, until:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been drinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets go and she steps back.   Studying him.   Scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been watching you sleep.   At night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gently) That's creepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes when I'm at work, I'll start thinking about you and I'll just get - just - overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dense, crushing - geophysical force. Like I'm pinned. At the core - where things change. (beat) You ever get that way about me, Jen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to describe my feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those don't sound like feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? (Beat) What's the sound of one feeling...in a forest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're so much smarter than I am. That must make you feel very powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helpless, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.     Maybe it's time to really talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.     Frayed and worn, she sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Whatever. I'll make you some dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her turn and head for the kitchen.          To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.     Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, exhales.    Looking down.   Afraid.    Gratefu happening at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be. Knowledge is pain.         I'm used to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer winces, feeling some sympathy.     Preparing her turn and end it, to grow, to move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like I don't let little pleasures, in return for the pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She frowns and turns - and her eyes go big with fear. Crawford is holding a semi-automatic pistol, aimed at her face. Very still. The gunshot explodes out of the muzzle - bright, harsh, l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gifford and his Grandson turn to look at the Crawford hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford stands, tilting his head to watch the slow hypno curl of smoke leaking from the gun in his extended hand. hand, we might notice now, wears a surgical glove. He lowers the gun, bends to pick up the ejected shell-cas from the floor. He wipes it and tosses it aside, on his w to Jennifer. He stands looking down at her: face-up on the floor, head a small pool of blood, eyes and mouth open. The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gifford leans on the frosted-glass panel next to the door hands cupped around his eyes, trying to see in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom?   Jen?   Everything okay in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford steps in from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody just LEAVE US ALONE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calmly aims up at the frosted-glass transom and fires three times - watching Gifford fling himself away. Crawford collects the shell casings, wipes them, drops th back on the floor. Peeling off the rubber gloves, he crosses to the fireplac and throws them into the flames. They curl and blacken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford watches, expressionless - then looks around, satisfied. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helicopters overhead, SWAT teams setting up. Nearby house have been emptied, gawking NEIGHBORS and media vans moved back to a block away. UNIFORM COPS pull aside the barriers as a plain-wrap seda rolls through. It pulls up by the SWAT Command Truck. ROB NUNALLY gets out, surveying the scene. The guy who sp his afternoon with Jennifer Crawford in the hotel is an L.A.P.D. Detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the Negotiator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.    What do we know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford waits, with the gun.    The phone rings.   He pi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally is standing by the open trunk of his sedan, weari Kevlar vest now - putting on his shoulder-holster over it Into his cell-phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Lieutenant Robert Nunally. I'm a hostage negotiator for the Los -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford hangs up.   Thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally grimaces, shuts his phone, shaking his head. But then he turns - with the SWAT Commander and everyone else - as Crawford's front door unlocks and opens a few inches Nunally considers this, looks at the SWAT COMMANDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then.   Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls his suit jacket back on, then reaches into the t for his back-up gun. He tucks it into the back of his bel concealed under the jacket. He takes a walkie-talkie and starts for the house. The spectators fall silent.    Radios crackle and hiss as heads up the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford watches Nunally's silhouette appear on the frost glass, from across the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door pushes open very slowly.     Nunally stays in th doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford studies him, staying back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of the vampires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally is confused; Crawford gestures at the flood-lit l outside. Nunally glances back, sees the SWAT teams and - down the street - the distant barricades, the media. He nods, steps in and lets the door shut.     Careful sil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I call you Rob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not vampires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not vampires.     Ghouls.   Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally nods, humoring him, glancing around. Sees the sma pool of blood where Jennifer fell. Plays it cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford, what do you say you give me the gun - so I can pay more attention to what you're saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your best shot? (Beat) So to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just think - maybe it would -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what: I will if you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally frowns, wary. Crawford moves to the coffee table in the center of the r holds his gun out over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We both put down our guns.      At the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford gestures to a chair across the room - by the foy door, near Nunally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We set them down and step away. (Beat) Then you can "pay more attention" to what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally studies Crawford...and the gun, hovering above th coffee table. Looking for a trick, a catch. But there isn one. If Crawford sets down his gun and steps away, he'll standing in the open center of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy ending, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally stares Crawford in the eyes - - then slowly takes his gun from his shoulder holster. Eyes on each other from across the room - moving very slo the two men cautiously set down their guns - - and step away.   Crawford smiles. Nunally smiles, too, reassuring and false. Begins to edge forward - alert to the possibility of a lunge for the gun having another weapon. But Crawford stays absolutely stil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford, your neighbor mentioned that your wife -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can call me Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom.   Your wife. Is she here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford gestures to a library alcove, behind him, out of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally begins to drift slowly to the side, to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think she is.     I shot her, Rob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally's nodding, edging to look into the alcove -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shot your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like I just suddenly - snapped. We were arguing - and I got the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - okay - I hear you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I shot her in the head.   I know it was wrong. (Beat) Are you listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Nunally is not. He's frozen - staring, shocked, at th back wall of the alcove - which he can now see. There's a big framed black-white photograph: a portrait o Jennifer Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally fumbles for his walkie-talkie, rushing past Crawf toward the alcove - - kneeling by Jennifer, who lies, face-up in a red puddle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie-talkie) We need a medic in here! Get the ambulance up! RIGHT NOW! NOW! NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally feels her neck frantically for a pulse - looking her open, vacant eyes for some sign -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no - God no - I can't - get a -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally desperately starts C.P.R., his hands getting bloo He stops to check her neck for a pulse now and then - - as Crawford slowly approaches from the living room, standing behind Nunally. Cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think I read somewhere that a good place to find a pulse is the femoral artery. It's on the inner surface of the upper thigh. If you put your fingers - you know, right up inside her dress -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally turns and lunges up, smashing a fist into Crawfor face. Crawford reels backward with Nunally - - the two of them falling with Nunally on top, beating Crawford furiously, cursing - - as SWAT COPS burst in, grabbing Nunally, dragging him b knocking into PARAMEDICS trying to get to Jennifer - - Nunally kicking, flailing, spitting at Crawford - who's face-down on the floor, to get cuffed. Nunally pulls free from the SWAT cops, distraught, angry going to retrieve his gun and shove it in his shoulder- holster, struggling to regain control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second - she's not dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally whirls - everyone freezing, breathless, falling silent. The Paramedics kneeling around Jennifer work - - as Crawford lies on the floor, staring at his wife. Lik she's a machine that defied astronomical odds and refused behave according to his calculations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer's stretcher is loaded into an ambulance, doors slamming shut and sirens kicking on - - as Crawford, cuffed behind his back, is pushed into the back seat of a police car. His eyes on the ambulance as i pulls away, carrying his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DETECTIVE uses a pencil to lift Crawford's gun from the coffee table and carefully put it in an evidence bag. Nunally stands back, watching the COPS and TECHNICIANS wo the scene - lost in his thoughts, shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally "wakes" - nods.   Absently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     I'm good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To avoid talking more, he heads out to the glaring lights chaos outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarm clock shifts to 6:00 am and pops on to local ne and traffic - - but the narrow futon bed is already empty. WILLY SLOCUM works at a laptop on his second-hand desk, l by a solitary lamp. He is in his late-20s, good-looking. Short hair, office-p but athletic, wearing mis-matched sweats from Eastern Oklahoma State College. He jots a final note, sets his yellow legal pad aside. As goes to the closet-sized bathroom, pulling off his sweats and starting the tiny pre-fab shower, we linger on the la screen: rental listings for a new apartment.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: The bare overhead bulb is on, revealing the concrete floo and painted-plywood walls. His clothes hang neatly on a length of pipe suspended by ropes from the exposed rafter Law school texts fill cinderblock-and-board shelves. The radio chatters.    Willy knots a tie in his crisp whi collar.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: Willy methodically packs legal folders from last night's "homework" into his big, battered briefcase. He has to wo to stuff all the files in. He pulls on his suit jacket, settles the shoulders, tugs his cuffs. Uncaps a pen, leans over a one-sentence letter waiting on the desk. Reads it over. As he signs, we glimpse: - hereby give notice that I will be resigning my position at the District Attorney's Office as of Novemb-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy savors the moment. Then he tucks the letter into an envelope, gets the heavy briefcase - goes to shut off the light and open the door - which swings about six inches, then clonks into somethi Willy grimaces.   Peeks out, goes to pound on a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Demello? (Beat) MRS. DEMELLO!    Your CAR!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. He sighs.    Shuts the door and presses a button the light-switch. There's mechanical grinding noise as the far wall slowly rolls up, letting in daylight and revealing an alley beyo the hanging clothes and cinderblock shelves. He presses the garage-door-opener button again, and hurri across the apartment to duck out under the closing door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy straightens and takes a breath, re-settling his sui jacket with an irritable glance at his landlady's car, pa sloppily next to the garage, blocking his door. As he walks away, down the alley, we rise up to reveal th hazy sprawling landscape of L.A. - and the towers of Downtown, rising ahead of Willy like Oz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Phil: I called you as a courtesy, and you start looking to take advantage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ancient fluorescent-lit cubby crammed with documents, files, notes, reference books. Willy on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not knocking it down to a Class C. My backlog of open cases does not mitigate the fact that your client tried to kill his brother-in-law with - oh, right, a "golfing accident"? Your client owns one golf club and no golf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLY (cont'd) balls - and the "accident" took place in the stairway of an illegal after- hours gambling club. Yeah, okay - I'll see you in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His cell phone rings.   As he gets it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I won't see you in court, but someone from this office will. You take it up with them, I gotta go. (switching phones) Willy Slocum. Oh - hey, hi, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assistant District Attorney NORMAN CHANG (mid-30s) throws door open without looking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wooton Sims?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy holds up a finger, talking into his cell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.     Wow.   Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman mouths "WOOTON SIMS?!" repeatedly during:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - short notice is...fine. No, I can. Black tie. Sure. What time? Okay. Yes. Thank her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, exhales slowly.    Looks at Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wooton Sims?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please stop saying, "Wooton Sims" over and over. It's starting to sound like nonsense words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay: go back to "Wooton Sims."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willy gets up and goes out, past Norman -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell did you get a job at Wooton Sims?! I can't even get an interview!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman follows Willy out to a central bullpen area where shared ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANTS work: MONA and GLADYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been here five years. I'm your supervisor. I graduated USC, summa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just going to pretend he's not talking, okay? MONA                            NORMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.                     I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really jammed-up all day, and I need to rent a tuxedo - for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tuxedo?! Oh, come on!     You are so full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Jotting notes) There must be a place that does that, right - same day? I'm also gonna need a messenger to bring it here. This is my suit size and my shirt size...I really appreciate this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona nods, taking notes as Willy gets out a credit card. Other DDAs are gathering to soak up some vicarious kicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wooton Sims buys a whole lot of seats to this charity opera thing every year, because Bob Wooton is the chairman of this committee -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bob" Wooton?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Enjoying, mock-helpless) It's what the man told me to call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna need to pick out a style, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy hesitates, in over his head.   A DDA helpfully does Travolta finger-in-the-air pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know - I just don't want to look like I'm going to the prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna go Classic.    Fix him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get you something Classic. (Picks up a ringing phone) Willy Slocum's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure it comes with cuff-links and knee-pads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's very nice: it's good to be back in high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Hanging up) Willy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her tone makes him - and everyone else - turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Beat) Our God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who art on the Eleventh Floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, startled, looks around. Approving nods, raised eyebrows. He tightens his tie and heads for the elevators

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no justice! There is no justice in the city of Los Angeles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: District Attorney JOE LOBRUTO, 50-ish, sits behind a mass oak desk, studying a thick file. Doesn't look up as a SECRETARY shows Willy in. Willy hesitates. Looks around: he's never been here. Flag wood panelling, leather furniture, windows overlooking th city. Finally Lobruto looks up, takes Willy in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William No-Middle-Initial Slocum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit. (As Willy does:) Eighty-four-percent conviction rate. That's remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a case load thirty percent higher than any other first-year DDA. (Beat) Of course - you also swapped more cases than the rest of them put together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy considers his options.   He always does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I offered my losing cases in exchange for two or three of anyone else's possible convictions. They couldn't handle their workloads, and I prefer not to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobruto knew this; the question was would Willy admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to need a middle initial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to Wooton Sims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be able to afford a better suit. But those guys all play squash and have middle names. They go in for the mother's maiden name a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Willy doesn't like the implied personal judgement, the only way it shows is how calm he stays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother didn't have a maiden name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobruto nods, unruffled by Willy's hard calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're a bastard; sometimes I can be a son-of-a-bitch. Maybe you belong here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't work this hard to stay where I belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a street-fighter, Willy. You should be in court. We can move you up to better cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate the offer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think so. (Closes the file, stands) Well - you got your litigation experience. Your chops. And your juicy private sector job. Anything else the City of Los Angeles can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy's amused.    He stands, too.   As they shake hands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think that's everything - thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The offer stands. If you get tired of carrying a spear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods - but Lobruto notes the tiny flicker in his ey not getting it and trying to cover. Lobruto smiles gently

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an opera joke. Give my regards to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy's twisting in his rented tux, trying to adjust a bu on the side of the vest. The phone rings and he gives up, frustrated - pushing the plastic garment-bag aside to answer - - knocking a full cup of take-out coffee on to his chair. Which is where he left his suit. Willy freezes. Watching the coffee seep into the fabric. Into the phone, distracted:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy Slocum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman's looking at a case file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an Attempted Homicide. Conley caught it last night, but he's hung up in motions with Gardner. Arraignment in Part Seven, at three o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three o'clock is in fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.   What's the temperature?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do still actually work here, Willy, right? I mean, you're still going to be cashing your paycheck for another two weeks and everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get somebody else for this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's booked up. Look: it's not going to trial. There's a weapon with prints, and a confession. Take the arraignment and wait for the plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Beat) A real confession?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spontaneous and signed.   Come on, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy sighs.     Looking down at his coffee-soaked suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Here's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman slowly smiles, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know - I really wish I was going to see this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy slips self-consciously through the double-doors, wearing the tuxedo. He gets even more self-conscious when he notices a handfu local REPORTERS. He hurries in - - passing Nunally, in the back row. Nunally is making a g show of keeping it together...but it's only a show. JUDGE IRENE FELDMAN, 50-ish, looks over her half-glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Slocum. Nice to see a man who dresses for court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, your honor.    Long story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, hurrying to Prosecution Table, barely glances at t Defense Table - - but Crawford, sitting beside his PUBLIC DEFENDER in an orange jumpsuit and handcuffs, never takes his eyes off Willy, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grapevine has it the punch-line is Wooton Sims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you, double-oh-seven. (Signaling the Bailiff) Let's see what public service is offering you by way of a send-off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State of California Versus Thomas Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Defense rises; Crawford hardly pays any attention to Judge - glancing back and noticing Nunally, whose eyes bo into him, haunted and burning. Crawford stares at him impassively a second, then turns t lean past his P.D. and watch Willy hastily skim the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford, you've been charged with section 664 slash 187 of the California Penal Code: Attempted Murder, with additional allegations of Assault With a Deadly Weapon - Penal Code section 245 dash A2, with Great Bodily Injury, P.C. Section 12022.07. (Beat) Do you waive further reading of the complaint and complete statement of rights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.D.                              CRAWFORD (sotto)                    I do.     But, your honor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you wish to enter a plea at this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not guilty. But I also want to waive my right to counsel, and represent myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy looks up from the file - startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a problem with your appointed counsel, Mr. Crawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just want to do it myself.     I believe it's within my rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, if I could have a moment with my client -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not your client. Try and keep up, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The P.D. shuts up, taken aback. The Judge considers Crawford, thoughtful, then turns to Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do the People have an objection or a comment for the record, Mr. Slocum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy hesitates, held by Crawford's strange, amused gaze. Shakes it off:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, your honor: we've got the weapon and a signed confession. I really think Mr. Crawford needs a competent attorney to - frankly - negotiate a plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford reaches up with cuffed hands and adjusts an imaginary bow-tie. Willy self-consciously touches where Crawford indicated on his own collar, straightens his cli on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford nods: you're welcome.    Willy turns to the Judg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - can't - this was supposed to be - with a pro se defendant, this is going to drag out for months - and I'm not even going to be here. The People request a continuance to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Your honor? I'm willing to waive my right to a preliminary hearing and go directly to a jury trial. (To Willy) Does that help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to look out for Mr. Slocum, Mr. Crawford. The District Attorney's office can shift another prosecutor to the case -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I like Mr. Slocum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Slocum?   He likes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford seems to understand his rights and responsibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All due respect, your honor, I'm worried this may turn into some sort of a - circus -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate your concern for the dignity of my courtroom, Mr. Slocum - considering you're making the argument dressed as a game-show host. Unfortunately, the man is a tax-paying citizen, entitled by our Constitution to try and manipulate the legal system, like everybody else. (turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE FELDMAN (cont'd) As for you, Mr. Crawford, I strongly urge you to retain counsel. Lack of same will not be grounds for appeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.     Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are the People ready to go to trial without a preliminary hearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy hesitates, irritated. Looks through the file again. Checks Crawford - waiting, polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   Why not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford smiles at him, as the Judge opens her calendar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, in his tux, comes out of a staircase and stops. Nunally is waiting by Willy's parked car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy takes him in - wary, seeing an edge of anger and fe beneath the tough controlled cop manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what I'm supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked around. You're supposed to be top-notch - but to me it looks like you've got one foot out the door, and you're wiping the rest of us off the bottom of the other one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to...disappoint you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally is silent - frustrated. The concrete walls and ceilings echo from distant cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took Crawford's confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you want mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to warn you. Take this seriously, because it's serious. This guy is stone cold - and his wife - is lying in a hospital bed - with brain damage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He struggles to keep himself under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna be on this, or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I'm on it. (Gently) You got a confession. You took the gun out of his hand. It's done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just - telling you. Is that okay? Or are you too friggin' busy?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy waits.    Watching the tortured cop wrestle with de

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. (Beat) It's a lock. We're good.   Put him down. Bury him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods.    Nunally turns and walks away, down a ramp. Willy watches him go. Sad. Like he's watching Nunally drown. But he's seen people drown before...and he's not about to put out a hand. Might get pulled in himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy moves uneasily among clusters of laughing, chatting sparkling FORMAL-DRESSED PEOPLE. NIKKI GARDNER joins him, strolling alongside. She's his a but her elegant dress, unlike his tux, was made for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a shark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been circling the lobby for half-an-hour now, like if you stopped you'd die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I stopped, I'd be standing around with no one to talk to. At which point, death would be a relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you talk to Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stops walking, getting a little careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bob" is talking to the Governor. (Beat) Do I know you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts a hand out, gently amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki Gardner. Senior Associate, Wooton Sims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shakes) Oh - hey, hi. It was your office that called, with the invitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Bob's orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I don't...actually know "Bob." I mean, I've only met the man once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki nods, considering this.      And him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're each conscious of an unexpected buzz of attractio The lobby lights flicker, breaking the spell a little. As the CROWD begins to drift toward the auditorium doors:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truth is, I haven't really had that much expos-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a conspiratorial head-tip, Nikki moves toward the pl doors. Willy follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stroll the emptying plaza, dressed to the nines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob assigned you to my team. I'll supervise your case-work, steer you through the office arcana, and generally keep an eye on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of like a mentor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of like a probation officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Willy nods, meeting Nikki's gaze as she looks to ma sure he's got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wooton Sims expects absolute loyalty and a hundred-and-ten-percent performance. But: you get to work on legendary litigation. National, sometimes global, in scope. It's high- stakes. And cut-throat - even within the team. We burn out associates at an astonishing rate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're trying to scare me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to try harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops walking.   Studying Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something personal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy doesn't answer. Maybe uncertain what she means. May not wanting her to know. Or even not knowing, himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a guy in our criminal division, fresh out of Yale, named Calvin Tyler. One of our very rich clients gets pulled over, D.U.I. - which is routine bullshit, so Calvin gets it. Against you. Next thing we know, Calvin is fired, and Bob Wooton, who has never even interviewed a junior associate before - let alone hired one - says you're on my team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy weighs his options.    Decides to level:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a good bust, so Calvin came to me for a deal. I told him if he could arrange an interview for me with Mr. Wooton, I would throw the case. I laid out his arguments and evidence for him - and I showed him how I would lose. Calvin set up my appointment for the day after our court date. Then he did what I had suggested in court - and I wiped the floor with him. Your client got the maximum. Next day, I met with Mr. Wooton. (Shrugs) Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. You know what's brilliant about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't actually do anything all that wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - I wasn't entirely honest with Calvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His cell-phone rings.    He ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone I need to talk to is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both feeling the electricity in the air between They wait the phone out, enjoying the forbidden insanity it. But then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk about your transition timetable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob believes in trial-by-fire. He wants you up-to-speed two weeks from Tuesday, because we're getting on a plane to Chicago for depositions in a class-action against our biggest client, Armstead Pharmaceutical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She studies Willy, trying to make sure he understands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's catch-up on three years' work - and you haven't closed out your old job yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good at trials.    Even by fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, a little bit of fear can be a very healthy thing to have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking forward to when I can afford the luxury of having some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki sighs, smiles.    Enjoying him, somewhat reluctantl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have them put the Armstead materials in your new office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.    Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her head off into the night. He remains, alone in his tuxedo, looking at the elegant glittering arts pla Then he checks his cell-phone.     Dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCHAND, Senior S.I.D. (Scene Investigation Division) Te works as he talks into a speaker-phone. He and Willy have teamed-up often, and an underlying respect lets them mock each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marchand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Willy Slocum.     What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your gun in that Palisades shooting is no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can the gun be "no good"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a perfectly good weapon. A Heckler & Koch nine-millimeter. It's just no good as evidence. It's never been fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the gun from the scene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Bought by Mr. Thomas Crawford and registered to his wife, about a month ago. Apparently a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And between the shooting and arrest, this guy was locked inside his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean, just: what's the point? Playing games with the gun. He's alone in the house with the victim, and he confessed - it's not like the gun's gonna get him off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a question I can answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Willy shakes the puzzle off, irritated:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, our weapon is in that house somewhere. Get a team out to search it tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sighs, smiles) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts the phone. Takes a moment, looking around again where he is. Absently tugs at his tie and vest, lets the case go. Heads in to the opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Controlled chaos. A week's work has emptied the shelves a cleared the surfaces, but the file-cabinet drawers are al half-open: Willy sorts folders, neatly marking and packin them. White "trans-file" storage boxes are piled all over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slocum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy looks up, at a MESSENGER with another file box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you want it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea here is we're trying to take boxes out - not bring more in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy sourly gestures to a chair; checks the label as the Messenger sets it down -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa - wait a second, this is a screw- up. I already have these documents. I sent this box: to the Defendant, at County.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I picked up at County.    Slip says bring 'em here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Messenger holds out a clipboard. Willy reluctantly signs. As the Messenger leaves, Willy cuts the tape and takes ou folder. Opens it: Crawford has scrawled NO in red marker across the top she Willy turns to the next page.     A big red NO across tha Pulls out more documents - flips through: NO - NO - NO - red letters wriggling across the typed pages, like flip-b animation. Beat.   Disturbed, he picks up the phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S.I.D. TECHS are taking the place apart: opening HVAC ven pulling books off shelves, upending chairs and tables, removing drawers from cabinets. Marchand, supervising, answers his cell-phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marchand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we on this gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't find it, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in trial on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I don't know what to tell you. I'm there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you'd get a team out a week ago -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here now. My team has been here twice already. (Beat) Do you really need it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I need it?! The weapon?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a second.   Sighs, exasperated - but honest:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Probably not. Defendant's a whack-job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went pro se, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just when you think they're not really stupid, they defend themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a confession and an airtight bunch of circumstantial. (Apologetic) We've gone over this place top-to- bottom three times now, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy takes a breath.   Thinks it through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. Don't worry about it. (Beat) Sorry - got a lot going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be rough, figuring out what you're gonna do with all that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I had to sit through an opera last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh gee - lemme see if I can express how much sympathy I have:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marchand snaps his phone shut. Willy smiles, hangs up. But then his smile fades, as he glances down again at Crawford's box of papers. Hundreds of pages.   Every single one scrawled NO. Willy considers them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal chairs. Bad light. Crawford sits, cuffed, at a tabl waiting. Looks up as the door unlocks. A GUARD lets Willy in, locks the door behind him. Crawford watches Willy take a legal pad, files, pens from briefcase, set them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard somewhere, I think it was on N.P.R., that you're supposed to talk to people in a coma. Play their favorite music. Supposedly it reaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, now ready, lets Crawford study him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You represent Jennifer. The voice of the victim, judicially speaking. But you haven't gone to see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too busy getting up to speed on Armstead Pharmaceutical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not judging you. I think anyone - coming from...what you came from - then paying your way through East-Okie Cowshit College and Tulsa Law by writing papers for Princeton kids on the internet - my God, it must have eaten your liver! Sixty-thousand dollars in debt, eighty-four percent conviction rate: you deserve this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy tries to stay in control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell have you been doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm permitted the use of a private investigator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to investigate me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?   You're investigating me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shot your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allegedly. That's how it works, right? If I can't introduce something in court as evidence - it doesn't exist. Legally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look - I don't want to play games with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Willy reconstructs his formal cool. Takes some page scrawled NO from a folder, pushes them across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this some form of - communication?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sent me a box of papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called Discovery.       The State has a legal obliga-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing in it, Willy. You haven't 'discovered' anything. Have you found the gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (Beat) Does it bother you that I call you Willy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Lies) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford nods.    Pleased.    Leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to consider becoming my lawyer. I'll pay you. A lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm - prosecuting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I'm offering you a chance to get on the right side of this whole mess while you still can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think - on advice of counsel - I'll decline to answer that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy studies him. Decides: it's an elaborate act.   Begi to put away his papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need the gun to convict you, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was cheating, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy looks at him, slightly taken aback.   He didn't kno wasn't in the confession. As he considers whether it makes a difference - he notice Crawford watching, enjoying. Willy shuts his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what she did...Tom. What you did is a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps. But - maybe my so-called peers will look at me and see themselves. Betrayed. Frustrated. Humiliated. And you and I both know, Willy, that people have an infinite capacity for believing in their own innocence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.   Take the stand. Tell your story.   I'd appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to mention the fact you have no actual evidence connecting me to the crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy smiles, gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except your confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford watches him go to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandfather was an egg farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stops, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this gonna be about how you had a rough childhood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to candle eggs at his farm. You know what that is? You hold an egg up to a light, and look for imperfections. (beat) The first time I did it, he told me to put the ones that were cracked or flawed in a bucket - for the bakery. (beat) He came back an hour later and there were three hundred eggs in the bakery bucket. He asked me what the hell I was doing. (beat) I found a flaw in every single one. Thin places in the shell, minuscule cracks. (smiles) Look closely enough and you'll find everything has a weak spot...where it can break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I've found yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Illuminate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford considers how to put it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a winner, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.   Willy pushes the call-button by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Well.      Joke's on me then, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you in court, Mr. Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door unlocks.   Crawford winks. Willy hesitates for a second - then leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's big. It's got a window. It's got a sofa. Undecorated except for a pile of materials & boxes marked ARMSTEA PHARMACEUTICAL. Willy is filling out forms - tax, citizenship, benefits. doesn't notice Nikki when she comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure you sign the one with the devil in blood. It's not binding otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just want to be ready for Chicago. I'm all closed-out, downtown. Last trial starts Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Not pleased:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a trial Monday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah: attempted murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gives you three days. You told me - and I told Bob - that you would be ready to hit the ground r-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man confessed.    And he's pro se.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, some but acting as his own lawyer - he could drag it out for months!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hear his witness list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki nods.   Willy is silent.     She frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No witnesses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy leans in, enjoying this part - analyzing, even admiring, Crawford's ploy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kind of clever: this guy is trying to provoke the system into declaring him insane. I think he thinks we'll call in the doctors and he can fake 'em out by refusing the defense. He's acting out this really - organized plan to appear crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Nikki considers Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna miss being in court, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies her, confident.    Gestures to the stacks of Armstead materials:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm almost halfway through these. And I think I've already found about six disqualifiers in Delaware, Ohio, and Florida. I have to check case law in each state, but it looks good. I'll get the rest done over the long weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki sighs, smiles a little, against her will.      He's over...again. Willy shrugs, grins.    In the silence, the impossible electricity returns.    After a moment - to defuse it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't go home for Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slight beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She studies him a moment, thoughtful.    Careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want - you're welcome at mine. My family's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. Smiling a little, knowing her family and starti to know Willy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it would be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.    Okay, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   She leaves.    Willy doesn't go back to work righ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE ROBINSON presiding. A mid-sized crowd, including a REPORTERS. A UNIFORM COP is in the witness box, Willy sta in the Prosecution Table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We established a perimeter around the house and then waited for SWAT and the Negotiator. It was strictly by the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the house was completely surrounded within how long of the first shots?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford sits alone at the Defense Table. He wears an expensive suit and no handcuffs, but two DEPUTIES sit beh him. He's barely listening to the testimony - drawing on legal pad: intricate, dense complex diagrams of "Rube Goldberg" contraptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when you arrived at the sc-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford noisily tears a page off his pad.     Looks up - Willy, and everyone else, turned to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy sighs, returns to the Cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you arrived on the scene, was there a crowd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Neighbors, came out to look soon as it started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And from what you could ascertain, no one went into or came out of the house until SWAT and the negotiator arrived?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.   No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford looks up from his drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your witness, Mr. Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford takes in the Uniform Cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No questions for this witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy watches Crawford return diligently to his doodles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a mess of loose legal-pad pages torn from Crawford's pad, each covered in madly intricate schematics. He works yet another, head down, intent. Dr. MARION KANG is on the stand, using a marker on a big diagram of a head:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - through the frontal cortex and the temporal lobe, coming to rest against the back of the skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this bullet inflicted serious injury?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It inflicted serious and irreparable injury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods, allowing the jury time on this. He checks a n card, glances at Crawford. Considers his options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Kang, is it safe to say that someone inflicting this kind of wound intended to kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Robinson gives Willy a warning look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford, you might want to object. The witness can't know your state of mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford doesn't even look up from his drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy gives Judge Robinson an I-told-you-so shrug.     Tu Dr. Kang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would say so, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dr. Kang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford tears off the page, starts another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally on the stand.    Focused, professional.   Crawfor draws, ignoring him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So after you put down your gun, what did Mr. Crawford do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He confessed to shooting his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He confessed. (Beat) Did Mr. Crawford appear confused or in any way intoxicated, impaired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not at all. He knew what was going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Mr. Crawford say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally looks at Crawford, enjoying the fatal blow:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said, "I got the gun and I shot my wife. God help me, I shot her in the head. I know it was wrong."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low, still drawing) Objection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone turns, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - Mr. Crawford, did you say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford sets aside his pen for the first time.   Looks u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   I want to object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what grounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you'd call it. They - it wasn't the first time, either, but - I don't know the legal term.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just explain it in layman's terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking the victim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uproar in the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said layman's terms -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - what would you call it - legally - when the officer who arrested you has been having sexual intercourse with your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utter silence. Willy whirls a look at Nunally.     The co meets his eyes - a deer in headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Low) Oh - shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's objectionable - maybe I'm wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Nunally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally looks down, silent.    Shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor, the People request a -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally suddenly launches himself over the witness box ra to attack Crawford - as the Deputies leap forward to stop all of them flailing and cursing in a tangle -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - spectators screaming, fleeing, gawking.   Chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge grim, Willy panicked, Crawford calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had my witness list.   He should have filed to suppress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugs) My mistake. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford, I warned you about representing yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the fact that it's true? I mean, isn't that the point here: to get to the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Slocum - is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I only heard about it five minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put him back on the witness stand if you don't believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't put him back on now! Not after what the jury just saw. Your honor, I told you this would turn into a circus. First he provokes the witness with an outrageous allegation -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Dick has evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge and Willy look at Crawford like he's truly insa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My investigator. I call him Dick. I guess I should call him as a rebuttal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRAWFORD (cont'd) witness? He's got phone records, credit receipts, photographs, videotapes - all documenting the affair. In graphic detail. (Beat. Mildly:) Dick is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge looks at Willy.    This is bad.    Thinking fas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay - um: I'll stipulate that my witness was less than forthcoming ...and that can more or less cancel out the fact that the defendant withheld a crucial -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Slocum - your witness was intimate with the victim, and he assaulted the defendant during the arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, while obtaining my so-called "confession."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stares at Crawford, shaken.    Understanding the tr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.   Your honor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a point. They were alone in the house. The confession is no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a legal argument?       "Oh come on"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Whirls on him) You want to get into it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford raises his eyebrows. Awkward silence.         Wi a deep breath. Turns to the Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. (Beat) He dictated and signed his confession, after that incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In police custody. Arguably, in fear for his life. I'm sorry, Mr. Slocum - it's all 'fruit of the tainted tree.' We have to exclude all versions of the confession and any evidence collected by Lieutenant Nunally or by other police officers on the night he was present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is insane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Biblical, isn't it?   The fruit and the tree and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He set this up! Don't you see what he's doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. And I don't like it. But it's done, so we have to deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I could go home today, your honor? With Thanksgiving around the corner -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't push it, Mr. Crawford. (Beat) What we're going to do is give Mr. Slocum a few days to regroup and come up with new evidence. If he doesn't - then you can go home. That's going to put us into the long weekend. We reconvene Monday morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy just stands there: blind-sided, shell-shocked. Crawford smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The end of a bad, bad day.   Willy flips on the lights as comes in, shaken. A package is on the empty desk. Addressed in red marker. The return address: TC, County Jail. Willy just stands looking at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford sits on the metal bunk in his prison jumpsuit. Alone. Looking down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willy takes a letter-opener from the desk drawer - the phone rings. He answers it, eyes still on the package:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy Slocum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded with UPSCALE YOUNG PROFESSIONALS.    Nikki is on cell-phone, hand over her other ear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - you've gotta admire the cleverness of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy begins cutting open the package as he talks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford very slowly raises his eyes, until he is looking directly at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Willy - give the devil his due.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm just trying to figure out what that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay: then listen - I checked with Bob on how he wants you to handle this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIKKI (cont'd) Has LoBruto tried to take you off the case yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he pretty much has to if he's gonna save any face. So here's the strategy: you let him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy cautiously lifts the box's flaps - pulls aside tiss paper - to reveal: A single eggshell.   Broken, empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I let him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford begins to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, damage control. Stop getting your face on TV. As it is, I had to talk Bob down from cancelling your contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy is staring down at the broken eggshell, barely listening to Nikki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we've got to move fast and get out from under. Otherwise, and I quote: "Stick a fork in this kid's ass and turn him over, he's done."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't just - walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy: today, you got killed. The issue now is saving your new life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy can't take his eyes off Crawford's "gift."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess...that would be the smart way of looking at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford stares right at us.       Smiling.   Ice cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki is sympathetic, misunderstanding Willy's quiet:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to come out and get drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thank you. I've got some stuff to take care of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.    Don't beat yourself up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.    Considering the empty eggshell.       But looks up: District Attorney Lobruto is in his office doorway, tryin decide whether to be angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look into who the victim was sleeping with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy burns, ashamed.       But unable to admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He - threw me off. (Frustrated) Look, Crawford knew he'd be the prime suspect, so he gave us everything - but he made it all radioactive. The night this went down, it was over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you still walked   it into court, Willy. We might not    have a case...but it didn't have to be   a public humiliation for this   office and the police department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you taking me off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're leaving anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starting to get a sense of this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not new evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take him now: he thinks he's smarter than I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about you, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is. He made it that way. (Shows him the egg) He likes me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that - some kind of Oklahoma insult?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me do this. I won't make you look bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You won't. That's what I need to make sure you understand. I remove you now: I'm covered, I took some action. (Beat) If you go on with this, when you lose - blame has to come down. And it'll come down on you. I'll have to investigate you for improprieties, incompetence - anything I can. In public. I'll hang you out to dry. For the good of this office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?
