dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said "when."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobruto grimaces.     He shakes his head.    Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.   It's yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods.   Stubborn.    Scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Local news on the TV: Willy pushing past media outside th courthouse; official photo of Nunally; footage from the standoff at Crawford's. The sound is low, and Nunally isn't watching. He's sittin on the edge of the bed...looking down at his gun, in his hands. A knock on the door "wakes" him. Beat. He sets the gun aside, goes to peek out the curtains. Lets Willy in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not easy to find.      I had to call Internal Affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - they put me on a desk - 'til this gets...sorted out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He uncomfortably watches Willy glance around at the half- empty liquor bottle, the mismatched suitcases and paper b full of balled-up clothes. And the gun on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got home - my wife already took the kids to her folks. Press is all over our front lawn. Friggin' vampires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He falters, haunted by the echo.      Willy doesn't notic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell were you thinking. You're on the job and you get called to your girlfriend's house -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know it was her house.      I'd never been there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was her name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know her name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy waits.    Nunally explains, reluctant to expose him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No last names. Her rules. We met at the same hotel room, twice a week - no phone calls, no questions. She didn't want us to know too much about each other. She said it was like...travel in a foreign country. No baggage - from our lives. Just us. Escaping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get the feeling she had rules because she had done it before? With other guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I don't know. Maybe. (Thinking, remembering:) No. It was all just this...crazy thing. For both of us. It was... real. You know? We didn't expect that, when we started. We didn't know where it was going. I had cheated so many times, I was numb - but she was ...new. And she made me feel like there was - some chance. To change. We were scared. It was like we were afraid to go forward, but we couldn't go back. (Beat) You always think you have time. To work it out. Or make things right. (Angry) What was I supposed to do?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were supposed to tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm married!    I have kids!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought nobody knew - so maybe you could just walk away clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I didn't think HE knew! OKAY?! Even - after. I thought it was just - massively fouled-up...bad luck. Like - God - telling me - something. (Anguished) I'm there. My mind is going crazy. I know the confession won't hold if anyone finds out. (Beat) I thought the guy was a whack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?   Well, he's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally won't look at Willy.      He just sits there, num

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything else you can give me. Anything that might get us some evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally shakes his head.      Willy grimaces.   Goes to t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...tried to warn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stops.    Looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You warned me he was smart. You didn't warn me you were stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally winces. Takes it. Willy feels a little badly. guys in a shabby motel room, in terrible trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we get the confession back in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy shakes his head.     Walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive search is under way. Marchand's S.I.D. Team has been doubled, back-up by a doz

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF'S DEPUTIES -
dialogues.text: - passing hand-held metal detectors along the furniture - - taking pictures down from the walls - - turning over mattresses - patting-down every item hangi in the closets - - wriggling into crawlspaces - poking into light fixtures recessed into the ceilings - - opening the air-conditioning unit, up on the roof - - ripping out Crawford's high-end home-theater system - - taking apart the Porsche in the garage. Willy paces the edges of the action, restless, edgy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stops in the doorway - watching a DEPUTY shut the stainless-steel freezer, open a wired-glass cabinet and p around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shake the boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cereal boxes - shake 'em. And there's a chicken in the freezer. Thaw it out, check inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Deputy stares like he's nuts. Willy doesn't blink. Deputy goes to shake the boxes, eyes on Willy: okay? Willy nods.   Moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hours have passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy steps out of the front door, because he's going sti crazy inside. Stands watching two TECHS walk the lawn and flower-beds with metal detectors. He notices, past the S.I.D. vans and Sheriff's Dept. blac and-whites parked in the driveway: Nunally, in his parked car, across the street. He meets Willy's eyes.    Worried. Willy can't give him any news. So he pretends he didn't s the question in Nunally's eyes, looks away. Takes a breat turns and goes back in to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting dark out. Techs pack equipment cases, carry them out. The place is a disaster area. Marchand watches Willy pace the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage?    Washer-dryer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the tool shed, and the roof, and the H.V.A.C. ducts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the door frames?    The floors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he do: rip open a door frame, hide the gun inside and re-plaster the wall before SWAT showed up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the neighbors' property? He could have thrown it over the hedges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We checked. (Beat) He might have passed it off to somebody, Willy. Had an accomplice, waiting, out the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy shakes his head, grim.    Pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't an accomplice sort of guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slows. Looking across the room at the big Rube Goldber device. As he moves toward it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a...guy who likes to show off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He examines the intricate workings, eyes travelling the clutter of metal and wires and motors. Checks Marchand - who shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy grimaces.   Fuming, relentless:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a physical object. It can't just vanish. We're missing something - some step in the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins walking through the crime, "the stations of the cross" - re-enacting it, starting from the front door, methodical, reciting it to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighbor sees her get home. He's already inside. She lets herself in. A minute or two later: blood-pattern says she's standing over there - he's somewhere around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stands where Crawford was.     Raises a finger-gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willy goes to where Jennifer fell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then he carries her back there. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy walks along the path defined by the drops of blood:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's gonna need time. To confess. When she's alone with the cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stops in the alcove, looking down at the dried bloo the discarded paramedic-supply-wrappers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neighbor comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods, comes out - crosses to the foyer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford shouts, "Leave us alone" and fires three more rounds: boom-boom- boom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So everybody knows he's dangerous - and she might still be alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they'll call the Negotiator. (Beat) Now he's got about ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's it. He stands there with the imaginary gun in hand. Looking around. Trying to think like Crawford. He can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy won't respond - because accepting the apology means admitting he's got nothing left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's night. The house is empty. Except for Willy, turning on lights as he gets to each room, turning them off as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you dare stay out? Do you dare go in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Studying framed photos: Jennifer - now and then with Craw in Italy, Bermuda, Colorado. Always a bit posed and forma when they're together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And IF you go in - Should you turn left or right? Or right and three-quarters? Or maybe not quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checking the contents of the medicine cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can get so confused that you'll start in to race, Down long wiggled roads at break- necking pace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No longer really looking for the gun.   He's looking for insight. Contact. A way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy wanders through Jennifer's spacious dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And grind on for miles across weirdish wild space, Headed I fear, toward a most useless place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He idly surveys the vanity, cluttered with cosmetics, ski care products. Lifts her perfume, sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Waiting Place... For people just waiting. Waiting for a train to go Or a bus to come, or a plane to go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notices a storage box on the floor, left partly-open in t search. He shifts the lid aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the mail to come, or the rain to go Or the phone to ring, or the snow to snow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high-school yearbook. An old photo album. A teddy bear. A snow-globe. A well-worn book by Dr. Seuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or waiting around for a Yes or No Or waiting for their hair to grow. Everyone is just waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stares down at the souvenirs of a lost life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dim, and silent except for the hiss-click of respirator, the monotonous beep of the heart monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for the fish to bite Or waiting for wind to fly a kite Or waiting around for Friday night Or waiting perhaps for their Uncle Jake

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer Crawford lies with her head wrapped in gauze, ey shut, plastic tubing down her throat held in place with t Willy sits beside her bed, reading Dr. Seuss:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a pot to boil, or a Better Break Or a string of pearls, or a pair of pants Or a wig with curls... Or Another Chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops reading a moment.   Watching her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy turns. A work-weary RESIDENT comes past him to chec the I.V.'s and monitors. He's about Willy's age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard it might - help - if somebody talked to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reluctantly) The man who shot her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RESIDENT looks up at Willy - who shrugs, uncomfortabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any chance...she might come out of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a member of the family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Getting out ID) Sorry. I'm with the District Attorney's office. (Beat) We don't have any other witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This woman had a bullet plow through her brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. But you hear about people waking up from comas. After everybody said pull the plug - they wake up. (Beat) You hear stuff like that all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear about Elvis and Aliens, too. All the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not impossible, though. Is it? I mean - why else are you keeping her like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   The Resident sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's not impossible. But even if she did, she might not remember how to talk - let alone anything about how she was shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was here alone before, she moved a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you just going to keep asking the same question in different ways until you hear the answer you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how it works with the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew I should have gone to law school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy watches the Resident go out. Then he looks back dow at Jennifer. Listening to the machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy wanders.   Tina, the assistant, waits in the doorwa He's trying to conceal the fact that he's on a fishing expedition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is all exactly how he left it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Browses a wall of framed photos: Crawford at crash sites, universities, engineering test-labs - awards, certificate articles from industry publications lauding Crawford as t Go-To-Guy for investigating mechanical failures of aircra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he was - distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was drinking. The past few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he was working on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands over unfinished Rube Goldberg device.   Tools l out on the work table - meticulous, organized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All distraught and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want coffee.    He said I should ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy turns, a little rattled.    Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I said no thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room where Jennifer and Nunally met. Cleaned-up now, anonymous, empty. Willy stands looking at it. There's nothing to see. He grimaces, nods - heads out, pa the ASSISTANT MANAGER waiting in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Willy comes out of the room - he slows, noticing the little gray plastic surveillance-camera-ball in the ceili

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do you keep the tapes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy considers it.     He's got nothing else to try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get a copy of October 9th?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have it for you Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kind of under the gun here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're short-staffed tonight and tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Seeing Willy's confusion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods, trying to pretend he hasn't forgotten:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.   Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faux-Tudor Hancock Park dining room.   Wealthy, but liv in. JUDGE LEWIS GARDNER, your basic Henry Fonda/Jimmy Stewart type patriarch, carves a turkey at the head of a long tab wearing a worn and gravy-splattered apron. Platters circulate in both directions among Nikki's older siblings (BURTON and SANDRA), their spouses, their children. Willy sits next to Nikki, who is high-stylish despite the fact that she's dressed "casual."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White or dark, Willy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything is fine, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off-duty, you can call me Lew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Gardner piles turkey on a plate and passes it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So - is everyone in this family involved in the law?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Nikki's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha ha. (To Willy:) Burton's a counsel for Sierra Club, and Sandra's ACLU - so they use the holidays as an opportunity to give me a hard time, because I can buy and sell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not actually for sale, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki gives Willy a did-I-tell-you? look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicole decided early-on that black sheep was the most effective role in which to distinguish herself from her siblings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know of any other family in America where the corporate lawyer who's going to make partner by thirty- five is the "black sheep"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - you may be lost beyond recovery, but maybe we can still convince Willy that defending giant corporations against injured citizens is not the best use of his skills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, sir. (smiles) It's where the money is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Scolding mildly) I believe that phrase refers to banks. And it was coined by a thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Willy remains polite, but won't back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Times have changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Willy) You don't have to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind; I get this kind of thing now and then. (to Gardner) Almost always from people with money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appearances can be deceiving, Willy. I grew up with eight brothers and sisters on a farm up in Fresno, and I promise you I saw my share of hard times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy considers his options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mom OD'd fairly frequently, so they put me in a Group Home. My younger sister is dead and my older brother is doing twenty-five-to-life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Willy looks down, begins to eat again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I usually do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gently) Yes.    I see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you will against the wife-shooter, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The click of silverware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice, Burton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Willy looks up at Burton, steady.     Shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not over 'til it's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That looked pretty over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, Willy's been taken off the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might not seem like it now, but that's a blessing in disguise, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods.   Beat.     To Nikki, uncomfortable:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki looks at Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taken off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That...doesn't make any sense. Lobruto has to do some kind of damage control -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked him not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.   Nikki is staring at him.    Angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are really stupid, did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy doesn't know how to handle this; everyone else trie be polite, eating and pretending not to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm - getting new evidence -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? The Evidence Store?! Oh, that's right - they open early the day after Thanksgiving. You're gonna be fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it ever occur to you I might be good enough to still win?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares?! Win what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man shot his -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted corporate, right?! You wanted to play in the big leagues?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to all that trouble getting yourself in - and then you just pay no attention to wh-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look - I'm sorry - can we not talk about this here?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki stops. Refusing to look around.     Ashamed at losi control, turns back to her food:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone eats in silence a moment - then Nikki tosses dow her napkin:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and walks out of the room. With an awkward glance around, Willy excuses himself and follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm sorry I didn't tell you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me, when I said Bob wanted you gone as soon as this thing broke?! Did you hear me say I went out on a limb to convince him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be better than damage control if I actually turn it around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what if you don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy has no answer. He doesn't think that way. And she sees that. She sees a young man from Oklahoma, in way ove his head. Desperate to get through:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't get it at all, do you?! You pulled a stunt to get yourself this job. Fine: you're a hot-shot! (Beat) Wooton Sims does not need hot-shots. Because you don't win. The firm wins. Bob wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Beat) And you just put yourself head-to-head in conflict with Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.   Shaken:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We told the man you're getting on a plane to Chicago, Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Painful silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki watches him dealing with it, sympathetic. The impossible feelings always running under the surface for have developed a darker, aching tone. If anything, strong

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe I'm gonna go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. (Beat) Call if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods. Neither one moves. Judge Gardner enters cautious from the dining room - breaking the spell. Nikki nods goodbye to Willy, and goes out quickly without meeting her father's eye. Awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some work to do. I need to call a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gardner nods respectfully, but doesn't move quite yet. Studying the torn-up young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what nobody understands about certain kinds of underpaid public service work? Now and then you get to put a fucking stake in a bad guy's heart. We're not supposed to talk about that when we visit a third-grade class on Career Day, and it doesn't get you very far into the country-club locker room - but it's hard to beat when you actually get to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy looks at the kindly old judge, a little surprised. Gardner shrugs: my two cents.      He goes to a side-tabl the Yellow Pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty.   Dark.   Willy lets himself in. He looks for the light-switch - finds only a complex computerized dimmer-panel. He tries it. Accent lights come on, buried in the living room planters He can't get any other pre-sets to work. The crime scene is creepy, lit like that. The dried blood black. Shadows stretch up the walls, strange. Willy grimaces, moves through it - sees another panel by French doors to the garden. Goes over - - and jumps back, startled -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - by Nunally, on the other side of the glass. Catching his breath, Willy stares. He unlocks the French doors and Nunally steps in, uneasy, haggard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally looks around - taking a pint bottle from his over pocket, uncapping it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks, then offers the bottle.     Willy hesitates, t it. As he drinks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to find the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy winces at the liquor and the remark, hands back the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Professor Einstein. It would also be good to find a couple of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLY (cont'd) eyewitnesses. If one could be the Dalai Lama, it would be even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - Willy: we need to find the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had three different teams here -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't leave between the shooting and when we took him out in cuffs. The gun is here. (beat) So we have to find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - we can't! You want to move on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nunally tosses something from an inside pocket of the coa - Willy catches it.       A Heckler & Koch nine-milli plastic bag. Willy stares down at it. Then at Nunally, who holds up: a bullet, deformed by impact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a guy in the Evidence Room, owes me a favor. Well - it's not so much a favor as I know stuff about him. He can trade this for the bullet from Jennifer, give us a ballistic match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who's gonna get away with a crime - this asshole, or us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy sighs.    Tosses the gun back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else have you got?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy watches Nunally stalk out through the big, strangel lit room. The front door opens, and slams. A little worried, Willy takes a deep breath.       Gets t He still has three days to break this open. Walking through the crime again. Playing it out in his mind. Standing in different places, getting different perspectives. Willy stands in the alcove.    Looking around. There's something here.     But he can't get it. His eye falls on the Rube Goldberg device.       Moves cl peering into the mechanism. Turns away: no gun. But now he's facing the big wooden bo of ball-bearings, sitting out in the middle of the room o the coffee table. Hide in plain sight. He walks over - pushes his fingers in, feels around. Nope. He sighs. Takes a ball-bearing, rolls it in his han Goes to the device - drops the ball in the slot. The machine is amazing. The ball rolls and leaps and clatters - lights flash, elevators rise and fall, at one point the ball lifts on a jet of compressed air - then it spirals out of sight and reappears somewhere unexpected - - until at the end the ball suddenly catapults out and sa across the living room - - to land neatly back in the bowl on the coffee table. Willy grimaces.   This guy is really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mess of courtroom exhibits, copies of evidence, lists, depositions, photos, diagrams, take-out food containers a coffee cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marchand surveys it.    The bleary end of a long day - si clues, dead-ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy.     There's nothing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy has barely slept all weekend. He shakes his head, reviewing the hotel surveillance tapes on a VCR/TV, stubb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guns don't just walk out of crime scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marchand waves copies of Crawford's evidence - stills pri from home-video Dick took at a hostage negotiation: Nunal doing his job, his methods, his routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two months before he shot his wife, this guy had his investigator watching the cop at work. He knew exactly how it would go down - and he didn't leave any loose ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what is this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy uses the remote. On the TV, in black-and-white: Jennifer and Nunally come out of their room and head for pool - indistinct figures zip jerkily in and out of rooms fast-forward - - until he slows it: Crawford comes to let himself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hotel surveillance.     From that day. He was there. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marchand watches over Willy's shoulder.    Shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to see it for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what?     They were out at the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unmade bed. Her panties. Man's gonna shoot his wife in the head, he needs to get himself all worked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stares at the grainy black-and-white figure emergin from the room, walking away down the corridor. Unconvince

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     Worked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marchand gets his jacket, pulls it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, go home. Tomorrow you go back into court and take your lumps - then you start your cushy new life, and you forget all about this one. (Hoping to get a smile:) And then you can lend me money and shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy says nothing.    Runs the tape back and then slow-m it forward again. Marchand goes out.    Leaving Willy alone, watching Crawf

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stands over crime scene photos and diagrams spread on his narrow futon. "Walking the scene" again, on paper. The whole apartment is an array of law books, notes, exhibits, marked-up depositions. He's staring at evidence he's already stared at a hundred times. He grinds the palms of his hands into his eye sockets, a moan rising into a yell - - as he sweeps everything off his bed in a storm of paper throwing books - tearing up printouts - pulling out drawe emptying them, smashing them on the desk - - yelling in a frenzy until his throat is hoarse, his sha garage apartment is trashed, and he's sitting, exhausted, his chair. There's a knock on the door. Willy frowns, checking the clock: it's two-thirty a.m. goes to open it - - revealing Nunally, standing in the darkness, a haunted shadow of the boyish confident cop we met making love to Jennifer Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's done. In the tool shed: taped to the blade, inside the lawn-mower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Willy can say anything - Nunally walks away. Willy doesn't move.   Watching the tormented cop disappea down the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy - in a clean suit and crisp suit, carrying his briefcase - hurries through, paying no attention to the SECRETARIES and OTHER D.D.A.s who watch like he's on his to his own execution. At his office door, he gestures for Mona to come in with Surprised, she gets up - taking with her an envelope with messenger-receipt taped to the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona watches Willy shut the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Maybe. (Hesitates) Can I ask you to do something for me this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write down your cell number. (As she does) Once my trial is in session, wait outside. I might call - and just hang up. If I do, I want you to come into court and whisper to me that we got a tip about the murder weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't decided yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona studies Willy - then accepts it's don't-ask-don't-te hands him her number. Willy nods, grateful. Turning for the door, she remembers the envelope in her h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh: this came for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes it, and as she leaves, checks the return address Wooton Sims. Willy grimaces, opens it. Inside are an airline ticket to Chicago - first class - and a handwritten note, on Wooton Sims stationery: We only win the favor of the Gods by making a sacrifice See you tomorrow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands in his empty office, considering the ticket and note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy steps off the elevator, into a crowd of REPORTERS A SPECTATORS outside the courtroom. He's startled for a moment: it's worse than he expected - dense buzz of talk in the marble corridor and all the eye tracking him like he's walking into an arena - a freaksho performer - - but he doesn't slow, ignoring the comments and question avoiding eye contact - - until he sees Nunally by the courtroom doors, his eyes fixed on Willy. Willy meets Nunally's gaze...moving on, giving back nothi Nunally watches Willy disappear into the courtroom, stare the closing doors - uncertain, on edge. Lost, no matter which way this goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gifford, the Crawford's neighbor, is on the stand. questions him, standing by the Prosecution Table. Behind him, the court is standing-room-only. REPORTERS, SKETCH ARTISTS, SPECTATORS. Nunally, sitting near the fro Lobruto, standing at the back. Crawford writes intently on a legal pad, filling pages wi dense scribble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So - between the time you heard the first gunshot and called 911, and the time of Mr. Crawford's arrest - you had the Crawford house in view?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I was very concerned about Jennifer. She was a lovely woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one but Thomas Crawford came in or out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Gifford.    No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Crawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford glances up at the Judge. Then at Gifford, as if he's just noticed him up there. Beat. Without getting up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the guy run out the back door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What..."guy"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other guy. The one who shot my wife. Did you see him run out the back of the house, carrying the gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy closes his eyes.   Gifford grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't see the back of the house. (Trying to salvage it:) I believe...the police went around back when they arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy immediately stands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-direct, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Crawford is standing too - with his handful of pages:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've also written a motion to dismiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection - I'm on re-direct!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge hesitates.   Both men standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what grounds, Mr. Crawford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prosecutor doesn't have any actual evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the middle of presenting -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of his witnesses are going to testify to the same facts: that my wife was shot and that I was, tragically, in the house at the time ...a witness - and, in a way, a victim myself. I'll stipulate to Mr. Slocum's entire witness list right now, a request a directed verdict or dismissal, per California versus Collier, 1982, and the Appellate court decision, v. Watrus, 486.19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stares at Crawford, stunned. As the Judge reluctant nods to the Bailiff to collect Crawford's pages and opens law book:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your legal skills seem to have improved over the long weekend, Mr. Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the Judge checks the citations, Crawford glances at Willy. Amused. Beat. Willy looks down - reaches into his briefcase, move his cell-phone out from under some papers. To where he ca get it easily. Looks back up at Crawford.   Smiles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Slocum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy and Crawford turn to the Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got any new evidence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have a moment, your honor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge nods. Willy nods down. Trying to focus. He's got nothing, and everyone in the room knows it. He can hear it, he can fee it. There's a restless, hungry edge to the crowded courtroom. He stares into his open briefcase: the cell phone. Next to it: the first class ticket and Nikki's note. Willy glances back at the gallery. Nunally's eyes burn in him. In the back: Lobruto frowns, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Slocum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy turns back to his briefcase.     He breathes.   Pre MENU button - selects SPEED DIAL. On the tiny screen, a list of names.    Selected: MONA/CE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona sits on a bench, a few steps down the corridor from courtroom doors. Cell phone in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stands at the Prosecution Table.       Hearing his pulse. Crawford studies Willy, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your honor? Can we signal the prosecutor from here on planet Earth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy's fingertip hovers over the cell phone keypad. and a path is chosen. Possibly for life. Next to the cell-phone, the ticket and the note.       Se tomorrow. Nunally sits forward.    Lobruto is watching intently. Willy doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Slocum?     Now or never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy won't look up. Nunally stares, agonized. Willy grimaces slightly, as if he feels his soul burning turning to ash and blowing away - - nods, closing the cell phone, sliding it under Nikki's note. Shuts the briefcase. Looks at the Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no further evidence at this time, your honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford begins to smile. Lobruto looks down.    A buzz rises in the gallery - - as Nunally gets up, furious - stalks to the doors, slam out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Robinson looks at Willy a moment - then at Crawford who has been waiting, calm and polite. Very reluctantly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motion to dismiss is granted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uproar.   The Judge bangs his gavel -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order! The jury is released, with our apologies -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - practically shouting over the chaos - REPORTERS hastily heading for the doors, pulling out cell phones -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and the Defendant is free to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford gives the Judge a gentlemanly bow of the head. Willy begins to pack his papers into the briefcase.   Ref to look up. The Judge and the Bailiff might be saying other things, b no one is listening - SPECTATORS swarm up the aisles, out the hallway - and the Court starts to close down. Crawford comes over to Willy, holds out a hand. Willy looks him in the eye.   Doesn't move.   Crawford sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even a broken clock gets to be right twice a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winks, and heads up the aisle. As Willy watches Crawford go out the doors into a clamor lenses, hand-held mikes, white-hot halogen glare and flas - he hears a buzzing noise. Looks down at his briefcase, moves the papers aside: his cell phone is vibrating. Willy stares at it, as if he'd forgotten the thing could used for an incoming call. The caller ID reads: WOOTON SIMS.   He picks up -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki sits at her beautiful desk with stellar views out t windows behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (It's an effort) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think - I wasn't keeping tabs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward silence.      She tries to get past it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen: what do you say I take you out tonight and get you completely trashed? Tomorrow's just a travel da-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - there's a gun shot outside the courtroom. Willy turns.    Shocked.    Screams and shouting in the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move with Willy as he shuts the phone and heads for th doors - faster, pushing out -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - into the echoing chaos of the corridor - trying to move the crowd - - shoving through to where people are yelling and cluster around a figure lying on the floor. Willy pushes closer, until he catches glimpses of: Nunally.   Lying on the marble floor. His gun in his life fingers.   Blood all over, from his head. Willy stops pushing. Won't let himself look away - the screams and commotion around him retreating into a numb b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then suddenly Willy looks up - as if he's been called - - to find Crawford, standing very still, in the crowd, on other side of the body. Everyone else is moving, talking, gawking at the body or averting their eyes - - except Crawford.   He's looking straight at Willy. Pleased.   Triumphant. Willy stares into Crawford's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The life support system clicks and hisses and beeps. Jennifer is curled into a fetal position, despite the tub and wires. Willy sits by her bed. Still in his suit from court, the jacket off, the tie loose. He's been there a while.   But now he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband said something...that I can't seem to shake loose of. He said I'm a winner. (Beat) And he's right. I can't lose. I can't stand people who lose. (Beat) I may have been working so hard to put some distance between me and...people like you - that maybe I messed up. I don't know if did anything wrong. Or what I should have done. I really don't know, any more...what I'm supposed to do. (Beat) But I feel like I let you down. Somehow in the...process. And if I did, I'm sorry. That's all. I just - I hope you...have...just, some... (Beat) Anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels stupid. Takes a breath.     Looking at her pale, drawn, comatose face. He stands, goes to get his jacket, lying folded on a tabl the door. Pulls it on, settles the shoulders, tugs at his cuffs. Gets his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the door, and as he opens it - he looks back. Freezes. Jennifer's eyes are wide open. She's staring at him.   Willy stands, breathless, watchin her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sliding glass doors suck open, Willy walks with the Resid from the other night:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was looking at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I understand -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she was looking at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beam of light slides across it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Resident tucks his flashlight in a pocket, draws a pi from his lapel. Gently sticks Jennifer's cheek. Willy winces, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Resident ignores him. Pricks her forehead - her chin her big toe. Each time she twitches. He runs his thumb along the sole of Jennifer's bare foot. It arches up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The normal reflex goes downward.   Up indicates brain trauma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in there. She was looking at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Resident sighs.   Sympathetic, but plain:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we have to tape their eyes shut. They all move - they make sounds, they twitch. You think they're dreaming. But they're not. It's just what's left of the system, sending broken signals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we do other tests? Like an M.R.I. or something? And I want a coma specialist to see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not authorized to order tes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get you authorization.      First thing tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Resident studies Willy.   Reluctantly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get the paperwork, I'll do what I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods, grateful. As the Resident heads out, Willy si by Jennifer's bed - protective, intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford comes in through the lobby: rested, well-dressed free man. He slows, surprised - - seeing Willy come off the elevators. Willy hasn't left Jennifer's bedside. He's in the same suit and carrying hi briefcase from the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Slocum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just...visiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't like you at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't got anything to gain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - right. That's my weak spot. (Beat) Ever think about what yours might be? Your flaw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I have. (Leans in) The truth about me is, Willy...I'm really not very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods.    Concealing the ace up his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure do know a lot, though. Got everybody all figured out, everything set up, like one of your contraptions. Then you just sit back and watch it all fall right where you want it to. Must be kind of...boring. At that point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an ounce of sympathy, Willy? (Beat) Imagine it - imagine she was yours. And you knew you were losing her. (beat) Imagine days. Weeks. Going through her desk. Her purse. Her closet. Alone. Staring at her clothes. Her shoes. Knowing this is what it will be like. After. (beat) Do you have any idea how hard it was to go on living - with her - every day, knowing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you had to, right? You needed time to set it all up...your "crime of passion."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are many kinds of passion, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  There are. (Beat) So - thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford frowns.     Starting to feel wary.   Willy sees Enjoys it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For sharing your wisdom. All your little helpful bits of information. (Beat) You were right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.   Willy winks.    He goes past Crawford and out the Crawford doesn't move - except to turn and watch Willy. Uncertain, for the first time since we've met him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy - still unshaved, unslept, in yesterday's suit - co off the elevator, fishing out ID as he passes a RECEPTION

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm just -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - going directly to the key-card slot by the glass double doors to the rest of the floor. He swipes his card and pu the handle - - but it stays locked.     Willy swipes his card again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me - I'm new, I just started - and there's something wrong with my card. Can you buzz me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you here to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work here.    Willy Slocum.    I'm new -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, realizing how he must look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki Gardner. Willy Slocum, for Nikki Gardner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he calls in, Willy sees Nikki through the doors - one a half-dozen ASSOCIATES trailing in the wake of BOB WOOTO They all carry expensive business luggage, except Wooton who is powerful, perfectly groomed, and two decades older

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second - never mind, here she is, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy goes toward the glass doors as Wooton comes through nodding deferentially to the boss, semi-apologetic:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...Bob - (To Nikki) Can I talk to you for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wooton glances back at Nikki, eyes saying: don't take lon She nods as Wooton and the team continue to the elevators staying back by the glass doors to talk with Willy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let him know what happened last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great - who do I work with on it while you're gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't work with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki: the man has power-of-attorney and a health-care proxy, he can disconnect her life-support whenever he wants. If we don't move fast -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki explodes - but quietly, not wanting the team to hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Willy, wake up! It's over! What is wrong with you - it's first year law: that woman could fully recover and swear he shot her and it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIKKI (cont'd) wouldn't matter. Double jeopardy! You can't take him back into court!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you - we bring a civil suit -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got no standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have to stick: we just need to get a court order for now - to keep Crawford from pulling the plug! With all the brain-power here, I'm sure somebody can come up with a pretext or call in a favor. Then we can tie this up in court while we arrange a state- appointed conservatorship - so we can protect her while we fight him on -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point, Willy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stares. Because she's drawn a line in the sand. One he already crossed, without truly understanding...and now he's standing out there alone - feeling the sand slither under his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is going to kill his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (Beat) What does that have to do with Wooton Sims?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy just breathes.   Vulnerable like we have never seen before. He looks across the big reception area, at Wooton and the team of associates. Some look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ding!   The elevator.    Nikki grimaces, frustrated - and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts for the elevators, Willy following -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not really just gonna let this happen, are you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I'm supposed to lose my job over your problems?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My problems?! Wait a second - this is not about my anything any more -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy grabs Nikki's arm to stop her, turn her around - an she shoves him away, hard, tears welling in her eyes - - Willy letting her go - as the Receptionist quietly call for help - - and Nikki hurries into the waiting elevator.     The As holding the doors lets them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is about taking a couple of goddamn weeks off to try and save a woman's life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors begin to close. Willy stands facing the cluster lawyers in expensive suits, their expressions ranging fro pity to contempt - - except Nikki, whose eyes are full of shame and guilt an defensive anger. As the doors shut across them. Willy doesn't move.     Confused, humiliated, frustrated. He turns when a bunch of OTHER LAWYERS emerge from the offices, ready to act as bouncers. People gawk from behin the glass doors. Beat.   Willy holds up his palms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother.     I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs open the paddle-sign on the stairway door, setti off the fire alarms as he stalks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy runs down the stairs furiously - - the clanging alarm, several floors above now, a little fainter. He suddenly stops - clinging to the railing, bent over. sways, dizzy, gasping - - backs up until he's against the concrete wall. Presses himself against. Listening to his own ragged breathing. Scared out of his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford stands by the bed, glancing over a set of forms metal clipboard. DR. LUNT, a senior neurologist, and a HOSPITAL ADMINISTRA wait. The machines hiss and click, keeping Jennifer alive Crawford signs the forms, expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy's walking alongside Judge Robinson, as they leave t building. The Judge is wearing his "civilian clothes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do the doctors say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People wake up out of these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the doctors say, Mr. Slocum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said...there's no way to really know. I'm trying to get them to run more tests - but I was there, and I'm telling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I have no probable cause to issue a court order against Mr. Crawford - and he's protected agai-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT ABOUT HIS WIFE?!   WHAT'S PROTECTING HER?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge stops - giving Willy a hard eye: I'm sympatheti but yelling at me is not a smart approach. Willy looks at the Judge a second - hapless, frustrated, scared - then nods and shakes his head and turns away - hurrying off through the homeward-bound crowds. The Judge watches him go.   Grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford is carefully preparing an elegant, solitary meal Music plays on his state-of-the-art sound system. He stops, noticing a pair of Jennifer's reading glasses, folded up by a note-pad and pen next to the telephone. He picks them up. Stylish, feminine. He goes to the trash, steps on the pedal to flip open the lid, and drops the glasses in. Goes back to cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobruto - at the dinner table with his family - looks up, surprised, as the doorbell rings. He excuses himself - - goes to open the door. Willy's outside: apologetic but urgent, near the end of his rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - but nobody else seems to give a damn that sooner or later this guy is gonna finish what he started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been home at all today, Willy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy looks down at himself: he's unshaven, in the same rumpled clothes he wore to court yesterday. Exasperated:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - I've been trying to get some-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a court order out against you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A restraining order. (Beat) You were at the hospital?       Talking to her doctors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy nods. Lobruto looks out at the confused, frantic yo man - truly sorry that he can't help Willy fight his way toward doing some good in this mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford hired a lawyer this time. They saw Judge Gorman this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to stay away from him, and his wife, and the hospital. He can have you arrested if you don't. (Beat) I'm sorry. (beat) I can't help you. I told you how it would go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stares a second, slowly understanding his situation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you do anything for her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy grimaces.   But nods.   Turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move with Willy out to the quiet street. The windows o the houses he passes seem warm and safe - and very far aw Behind him, Lobruto watches from his lighted doorway. Willy walks, shaken, determined, into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NURSE checks Jennifer Crawford's vital signs. She then begins to gently wash Jennifer's face, where it's not tap or bandaged. The monitor beeps, the ventilator hisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford knots his necktie, studying himself in the mirro Expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge Gardner pulls his car out to the street - - swerving hastily, as Willy's car skids alongside and fo him to the curb, horn honking. Willy pulls to a stop, blocking Gardner's way, and gets o of the car - holding up both palms: just wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lunt takes a chart from the I.C.U. Nurses' Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Mrs. Crawford been prepared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford drives, wearing a dark suit, sunglasses.   Calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy watches GARDNER'S SECRETARY bring in a document, fr off the laser-printer. As Gardner signs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I use your fax machine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These have to be served in person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy brakes as he drives around a corner and sees a DRIV wrangling with the BOOTH GUY. He grimaces, looks around - - backs up, tires squealing, heading for another exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lunt stands by Jennifer's bed, supervising the Nurse an Orderly as they prepare her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford walks in, goes toward the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He floors it, racing under a light going red - narrowly misses getting broad-sided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lunt looks up from making notes on Jennifer's chart, Crawford enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy pulls into a NO PARKING zone and jumps out, papers hand - tossing the keys to an ORDERLY smoking a cigarette

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it if you need to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - running through the automatic doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing beside Dr. Lunt, Crawford watches, expressionles - as the Nurse and the Orderly work, efficient and silent disconnecting the oxygen tubes, unplugging the monitor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy dodges people, coming to the elevators - which open Too crowded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy gasps a little as he hurries up the stairs -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - comes out of the fire stairs, hurrying toward I.C.U. -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and into Jennifer's room, where he stops.     Shocked. The bed is being stripped, the equipment rolled out. Willy stares, breathless, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just missed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just went on up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy struggles to control his emotions.     Looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long ago...did she die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (Beat) The roof. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NURSE (cont'd) Medevac transfer. Out to a long-term care facility up in Santa Barbara. They just left, you can probably still catch 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy tries to understand her.   With growing horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's - moving her by helicopter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the surge of a jet engine - - as Willy runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Sikorsky S-76 Medevac chopper is preparing to take off, very loud and windy. Through the open doorway and the thick windows, we can glimpse Crawford sitting beside Jennifer, who is strapped to a gurney. She's connected to life-support equipment. The MED TECH is outside, checking a few last supplies and giving Crawford a moment alone with his wife. Crawford moves. He may be whispering to her.    Or adjust her pillow. Hard to tell. As he climbs out of the chopper - - he sees Willy across the roof, arguing with Dr. Lunt, w is skimming the court documents, shaking his head. Crawford, curious, walks toward the two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Lunt hands Crawford the court order. As Crawford read them, Lunt and Willy shout over the helicopter engine:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This orders him not to take her off life support! He's not! We can't stop the man from -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then just hold it - for a couple of hours! Have it inspected!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about a phenomenally expensive delay, Mr. Slocum - when the man has every right to move his wife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not gonna get there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Crawford: reading - amused, thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is a mechanical engineer with expertise in air crashes! He has access to airfields and he knows exactly how to make it look like an accident! You know what he did! You know why she's like this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunt hesitates, feeling a tiny edge of doubt. Crawford checks his watch.   Looks into Willy's eyes - - then gestures for Willy to join him, and turns back to across the pad to the helicopter. Climbs in. Willy stares, stunned. Lunt looks at him: case closed. The rotors whirl faster, engine noise rising to a scream. From the open chopper doorway, Crawford looks at Willy ag and gestures for him to get on. Willy doesn't know how to react.   Slowly, he starts to w toward the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy bends, coming to the door - wind-whipped, flinching Crawford holds out a hand to help him in. Willy doesn't move.   The PILOT glances back. Crawford's eyes are locked with Willy's. Willy stares at Crawford, scared. But unable to back down from the crude, plain challenge. Which Crawford is clearl counting on. Angry, at himself, Willy climbs in without taking Crawfor hand. As he nervously figures out how to buckle himself i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the Med Tech secures the door, the Pilot turns to face front - and they lift off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking directly down at the Sikorsky as it glides over a picturesque mapscape of streets and freeways, gray and te cotta rooftops, blue kidneys and rectangles of pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy watches Crawford, who stares back at him.       Cal Glances uneasily at the Pilot, bug-headed in sun-goggles headphones. Flying them, calm. The Med Tech, adjusting Jennifer's portable ventilator. Calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sikorsky glides over cross-hatched parking lots, a pa swath of beach - - and the white foaming edge of the Pacific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy looks up from the view.       Scared.   Yells to th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we going out over the ocean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy looks at Crawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep dark vast blue.   The Sikorsky flies over.      Smal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stares into Crawford's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he looks around at the vibrating metal box carrying hundreds of feet above the earth. The sunlight glare in t scratched windows. The blur of the rotors against the emp sky. The edges of the door frame. The rivets in the roof. Crawford's eyes.   Amused. Willy unbuckles his seat-belt, lurches toward the Pilot -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to turn back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in your seat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's doing something - we have to turn back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's doing something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy points to Crawford, who's just sitting there -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is!   You have to get us DOWN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back in your goddamn seat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy, I'm not doing anything. Everyone can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm TELLING you, we have to TURN BACK! He's DOING SOMETH-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alarm begins to shriek - on the ventilator. Everyone turns as the Med Tech hastily kneels next to it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know - I'm - there's a - malfunction -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Willy whips around to look at Crawford, with fury in hi glare: oh, you bastard. Crawford almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Med Tech is flipping switches, checking wires -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do anything with this, up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pilot turns - steeply, Willy falling over, the Med Te supplies spilling - as the Med Tech hastily removes Jennifer's breathing tube and prepares to begin C.P.R. -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's D.N.R.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Med Tech looks up - startled.     Confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy watches, wide-eyed, as the Med Tech grabs up his paperwork, searching it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Med Tech looks up at Willy, scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's Do Not Resuscitate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy turns on Crawford.   He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in her living will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Med Tech looks at Willy, paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's D.N.R.    She signed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a restraining order - she's protected - I'm authorizing you to do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Med Tech turns to Crawford, uncertain -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No extraordinary measures. (Turns to Willy) Unless your court order specifies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRAWFORD (cont'd) contravening her living will. But I don't think it would. I think you got one that forbids me from disconn-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy throws himself at Crawford - attacking him, as the Tech grabs him, drags him back -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON BACK THERE?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the Med Tech holding Willy down on the floor by Jennife stretcher - Willy struggles furiously -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!    WAIT - LOOK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy is pointing at Jennifer - shocked - - as the Med Tech lets him up and they kneel by her, the Tech taking her pulse - Willy, staring down at her, inten She's breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.     Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy whirls around to Crawford.        Who's frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You messed up. With all your plans and games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy turns back to Jennifer. Delicately strokes the side her face. Her eyes flutter open -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh.    It's okay.       It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - she stares into Willy's eyes. He takes her hand. awe in her eyes. Yearning. Fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She squeezes his hand.      Very weakly. Crawford is looking daggers: die, bitch. Jennifer's eyes - fixed on Willy - roll back.        She

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer?       Hang on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something sad in her wordless gaze.        As it starts t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer?!     JENNIFER?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's slipping. Her eyes gone empty.        Her hand beco lifeless in his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.     Come on, Jennifer.    Fight back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears well up in Willy's eyes, but he struggles against t feeling Crawford's gaze, refusing him the satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's gone. He stares down. Mourning her. Letting his grief slowly burn into rage. He gently reaches up and clo her eyes. Then he looks up at Crawford, who smiles sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pushed it, Willy. We didn't have to be here. (Beat) But now you're my witness. You saw: I didn't touch anything, I didn't do anything. The machine went down. Anybody asks - you'll have to tell them. What you saw. (Beat) That's really kind of perfect, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy stares into his eyes. Cold.        Then he looks aw the window, into the sun-glare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage door is open, letting in daylight. We can see alley especially well, because there are only empty hange on the clothes-bar, and the cinderblock shelves have been taken apart, stacked on the floor. Willy is packing.    He's wearing jeans, an old t-shirt. He carries a heavy pile of legal textbooks out to the tra bins, throws them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he turns to go back in - he sees Lobruto coming along alley, wearing a suit. Surprised, waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not answering your phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's kind of an answer in itself, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy heads back in, starts to pack again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you headed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't decided yet.    Just someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobruto nods.   Willy packs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have let it get so far out of control. (Beat) We all lose, Willy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just have to live with that, and keep fighting the good fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I was doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You belong in a courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy packs, thinking about that.   Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to - get to know myself better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good lawyer. All this may have even made you a better lawyer. Don't waste it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy turns on him - angry, confused, bitter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't just lose a case!     I let a man get away with murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobruto nods. Respecting his pain.     Shrugs, accepts th decision, with regret. Willy nods his thanks, and turns back to packing. Lobruto starts to leave.    But from the alley door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it makes you feel any better - technically, you let a man get away with attempted murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy doesn't respond.    Keeps packing. Lobruto goes out. After a moment, Willy stops.    Looking up.   Something t over in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobruto is walking toward his car when Willy steps out of garage and calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife is dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobruto turns.   Uncertain what Willy is getting at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can still get him.    We can take him back to court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gently) Willy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willy comes toward him - excited, insistent:
